Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Student Travel for Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop at International Conference on Functional Programming 2017 (PLMW@ICFP)

A Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop for students is being organized as part of the 22nd International Conference on Functional Programming (ICFP), one of the premier conferences in the area of programming languages. The conference will be held in Oxford, UK. This grant will support approximately 9 students to attend the mentoring workshop plus the ICFP conference and its satellite events. This proposal is intended specifically to target women students and students from underrepresented groups and gives priority to US citizens and permanent residents. The broader significance and importance of the grant relate to the need to broaden participation, provide opportunities for students to receive mentoring from leading members of the programming languages community, and build the next generation of researchers and knowledgeable practitioners in this important research arena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded 13 undergraduate, masters, and PhD students to attend the Programming Languages Mentoring Workshop at the International Conference on Functional Progrmaming, 2017 and 2018.  The meetings consisted of technical talks, professional development, and networking with leading researchers in the field. Of the 10 NSF-funded pre-PhD students, at least 5 have since enrolled in PhD programs in computer science.

The 2017 PLMW@ICFP featured both professional development talks, such as a talk on what not to do during your PhD; we also included a skill talk on how to write papers and give talks. One technical presentation provided an introduction and overview talk on the very active research area of gradual typing which also pointed students to various talks on at the main ICFP conference. The technical talks provided a short glimpse into various research topics.  In general, our goal was to showcase the diversity of people working in programming languages, the diversity of their background, their careers, and personal lives. We were particularly careful in choosing the panelist for the final panel and open discussion, as we wanted to emphasize the breadth of opportunities and also aimed for panelists who were not afraid to share not only their success stories but also how they overcame challenges.
